results.title: Wood joints
results.creator_credit: Moreland-Latchford Productions, James McCormick and Joe Jayward
results.brief_description: Precise camerawork shows clearly how the end butt joint is made, how to make a rabbet joint, how a dado joint is formed, and the difference between the dado joint and the groove joint. Also demonstrates the technique of using dowels to add strength to a joint and how to make a lap joint.

results.title: Wood Finishing
results.brief_description: Frank Klausz in this videos demonstrates the following skills: how to use a smoothing plane, a scraper and sandpaper; how to choose among oil, alcohol and water stains; how to apply tung oil or spar varnish; how to spray Lacquer; and how to French polish your work to an exquisitely glossy finish.

results.title: Wood
results.creator_credit: CSIRO, S.T. Evans and Nicholas Alexander
results.brief_description: Explains the structure of wood and the manufacture of plywood, hardboard, particle-board, pulp and paper. Shows milling, seasoning and preservation techniques and the development of planatations.

results.title: Wonders of weather. - Volume 3
results.brief_description: Snow: topics covered include how snow forms; wet vs dry snow; the last ice age; snowflakes and their life cycle, the work of Wilson Beckley, famous for photographing 5,500 different snowflakes through a microscope; Inuit people (Arctic circle) who have 40 words for snow (spoken with translation) and build igloos (see “Nanook”(505446) for excellent footage of igloo building); avalanches - including strategic use of them in WW1, the impact they had on Hannibal’s crossing of the Alps, and modern control by explosives; blizzards; glaciers and the effect of ice caps on global climate. “Fog”: topics include what conditions create fog, dew and frost; humidity; famous disasters resulting from fog and efforts of prevention (WW2 airstrips, fog horns, fog “seeding”); San Francisco (in fog 85% of year) and the coastal giant Redwoods dependence on these fog conditions; collection of fog as water supply to lower desert areas in the Andes; English “dew artist” Chris Hunter; differences between hoar-frost, fir-frost and rime-frost; frost damage to crops, methods of prevention and environmental consequences of this; smog, including details of the famous 1952 peas souper of London that killed 4,000 people in 5 days and Mexico City which has the worst smog in the modern world. “Signs in the Sky”: topics include descriptions of weather phenomena seen in sky, what creates them and how to read weather signs - types of cloud and how they were named; rainbows and fogbows; Brocken Spectre; halos; Silvan shine; mirages (prevented John Ross finding north west passage to Greenland); auroras and eclipses.

results.title: Wonders of weather. - Volume 2
results.brief_description: Three 25 minute segments dramatically explore the subject weather in “rain and floods”, “deserts” and “tornadoes”. The first segment clearly explains what influences and creates the water cycle; differences in cloud formation and the life of a cloud; how and why light or heavy rain falls, and looks at the causes and effects of extreme flooding using the Mississippi and Bangladesh as main examples (also why Hawaii is wettest place on earth but does not suffer flooding). Contains many tidbits of interest, including an easy class experiment on how to measure a raindrop. The second segment looks at deserts and the geography and climatic conditions that form them, specifically the Sahara, Kalahari, Gobi, Antartic, Death Valley and Mars. Includes how sand dunes are formed (some are stable for centuries, others are dynamic), and Bedouin and camel adaption to desert extremes. The third segment looks at tornadoes, “the most violent weather phenomena”. Explains how and why they form and develop, why they are so powerful and sudden, and the best defence. Focuses on “tornado alley” (Kansas, Oklahoma and Texas), and the tornado “chasers” - newsmen and scientists who go to extreme lengths to predict the location of the next tornado. Dramatic and interesting visual images throughout.

results.title: Wonders of growing plants. - 2nd. ed.
results.brief_description: Two children plant lima beans in a glass with blotting paper that soaks up water to keep the seeds moist. Time-lapse photography is used to show the growth of the plants. Other methods of growing plants, such as from roots, stems and leaves are shown. No other credits available.

results.title: Wonders in your own backyard. - 2nd ed.
results.brief_description: This film is designed to stimulate close and early observation. It shows a group of children finding a snail, grasshopper, earthworm, sowbug, spider, caterpillar and inchworm in their backyard. Suitable for upper primary level.

results.title: Wonders in the desert
results.brief_description: A young girl and her younger brother take a walk in the desert, where they discover an adult and a baby jack rabbit, a wild female burro and her young one, a lizard, a horned lizard, chuckwalla, a pocket mouse and a desert tortoise.

results.title: Wonders in a country stream. - 2nd ed.
results.brief_description: Encourages the observation and appreciation of small living things by showing children near a stream discovering tadpoles, frogs, damsel flies, newts, a turtle and a water spider. Suitable for primary school children.

results.title: Wonderful world of the Brothers Grimm
results.creator_credit: Turner Entertainment, Cinerama, Gallen Films, George Pal and Henry Levin
results.brief_description: Brothers Wilhelm and Jacob Grimm (Laurence Harvey and Karl Boehm) are commissioned to write a family history for a local Duke; the setting, the nineteenth century. The task seems doomed as Wilhelm is far more content creating stories about fairies, elves, knights and princesses to include in a collection of folktales. Jacob reluctantly agrees to help his brother, provided it doesn’t interfere with the serious task at hand. This fictionalised account of two of the world’s greatest story tellers is interspersed with adaptations of some of their stories. An international cast brings to life some of the Brothers Grimms’ best loved fairy tales including “The Dancing Princess”, “The Cobbler and the elves” and “The Singing bone”. The cast of these fairy tales includes Claire Bloom, Karl Boehm, Walter Slezak, Oscar Homolka, Barbara Eden, Yvette Mimieux, Jim Backus and Beulah Bondi. A delightful account that will be enjoyed by viewers of all ages.
